messageBody:
On Thursday 26 May 2005 15:59, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> >
> > The code still does something reasonable from the standpoint
> > of the object. Obviously the algorithm may be changed. For
> > instance, I can call drawLine before drawRect, in which case
> > the rect is drawn on top of the line if they overlap, or I
> > can call them in the reverse order in which case the line is
> > drawn on top. But from the perspective of a Graphics object
> > neither order is wrong.
>
> How about a real-world example? :-)
>
> Such as opening a database connection and then making a query?

The querayable object takes the connection as argument in the
constructor, surely.

> Or ordering
> methods and then calling them in that order?

"The code still does something reasonable from the standpoint
of the object" (Elliotte Harold, above).

> Or creating widgets, adding
> listeners and then starting the main Swing thread?

Nothing stops you from starting the thread before creating widgets,
does it?

> It's good advice, it's just impossibly hard to achieve in reality.
> Otherwise, we would never need setters.

Doesn't follow. You are confusing the "ordering doesn't matter"
property of various methods on an object - ie, that each ordering
makes sense from that object's viewpoint, no order is more "right"
than another - with the "ordering matters" viewpoint of the *user*
of that object desiring a *specific effect*.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
